text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Previously, we’ve been letting people stay on the testosterone. They feel good plus their scans don’t look any worse. I think given that your PSA went up, you’re feeling good, and the scans are a little worse, maybe you should come off it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And think about what’s next. Patient: Yeah. What is next? Doctor: Yeah. That’s the hard part of the day. Uh well I guess the first question is you sort of came here specifically for this. Are you going to, do you want to stay here for the next or is the next, do you want to go somewhere, to shop around? Patient: No, no. I, I came here because Dr. T___ out at S__ say, say, oh, you know, certainly recommended it. I guess he’s part of this study too, so. Doctor: He is. He is. Patient: So uh he felt pretty strongly that coming here to participate but also to, to say here is- Doctor: Remind me again how you hooked up with him. Patient: Yeah. Through the urologist that I had that did the surgery. Doctor: Because you’re mostly east coast. You, you moved?

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: There’s a part over Canada where you cross, there’s like a big bay, I think the jet stream. It gets real choppy there. You get a lot of turbulence. I always know- Family Member: Yeah. We did. Doctor: And one time, I don’t know where I was, but I remember looking out the window. I could see Greenland. Doctor: I could see actually. Because usually when the times I’ve flown, it’s either dark or cloudy, but this is one like, holy crap, and my phone even said, welcome. Doctor: You know when you fly sometimes, your cell phone will pick up. I must not have had it turned off. It said, like welcome to Greenland. (Laughter) Patient: Oh, shoot. Oh, God. Doctor: But that’s a lot of travelling, man. Family Member: It’s very interesting. Patient: Oh, my goodness. Whew. That plane ride was a trip. Family Member: We was, uh, kind of like laughing come down here to Baltimore. We were like, Baltimore’s not too far from South Africa with the living conditions. You know? Patient: With how some of these people live. Doctor: Yeah.

text: Family Member 2: I saw here when I… Patient: She seems good. Family Member 2: Who’s that, K___? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And he – when he saw me he had been through the XTANDI treatment and had started showing signs of progression. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So we did tissue testing because one of the ways of resistance is if they had that P10 loss which your tissue did. And that’s why we put you on this uh medication that at least you’ve tolerated amazingly well. I mean you really haven’t had any side effects, haven’t felt any different, managed to keep up with everything you want to do. So that’s been remarkable. The PSA last couple of times as we discussed last time has been going up. Okay. One of my concerns is if it keeps going up but the scans don’t change, do we stay the same course? And honestly for how well you’re doing, that’s what I’m tempted to do. Okay. If however your bone scan shows me new areas or things growing then we are going to stop this treatment and go to something else. Patient: I see. Doctor: Now as we sort of discussed a little bit, the something else could either be going back and doing chemotherapy with Dr. K____ okay that’s a potential option. And, or if we want to give it one more try with doing a different kind of hormonal therapy, we have a new hormone therapy agent that we are testing here you know that’s been through multiple people who have had it and there’s been some promising results initially so I think that would be another option. Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: But you know so those are probably the potential choices. The third possible choice and that would depend on your CAT scans had some lymph nodes though that were seen so there is a study with a combination of two different therapies. Okay? One is the Xofigo which is a radiation treatment that’s approved. You’ve probably heard of it I know.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But, your earlier ones prior to July were sort of January/February time point. So, if I just take down the bone, you’ve had a variety of different reports, right so your January one was lots of different spots and then I think your July one we don’t have an official report but it didn’t seem to change much, you know, kind of different spots, but then on the CAT scan it only just showed one area because it was such a limited area that I would imagine that your bones still have multiple spots. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We know that your PSA hovers around the one twenty nine, one thirty mark. It’s kind of been staying there. It’s not five hundred but it’s not fifty, Patient: Right. Doctor: but it’s enough to say this might be the reason why, you know, you’re getting more tired and having some pain which may not be related to that. Now, your actual CAT scan reports are always a little inconsistent so that’s why I think it’s not confusing but challenging. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, your January/February scan had maybe something on your adrenal glands, maybe something in your liver, maybe some clumpy lymph nodes, and you’re like oh, okay. So, when I sent you over for like additional, you know, trials you had areas to measure outside your bone but then you kind of don’t. So, on your last CAT scan we couldn’t see anything where the liver was so that’s just not there, the lymph nodes kind of where the adrenal area was is enlarged so you don’t fit that. Oh, that’s wonderful. You made my life a living bleep when I was like oh, yay, but oh, yay, oh, yay, oh. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I’m thrilled that you don’t have the cancer that we say earlier that might have been from the pills you were on Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: but then I’m kind of stuck in terms of well, I’m not really sure if I know where you are right now in October. So, sometimes when I get a little bit stuck and I’m trying to well, there’s this and that, just stop. It doesn’t have to be a mystery because we can just do a full set. So, like you should get a bone scan because the last time was July and we’re in October. You’re in pain so maybe I got to look for new spots that we have to try to treat. That’s one. Then, you know, a bone scan and then a CAT scan, but one that also includes the chest to make sure I’m not missing anything up higher that maybe is causing some of the lower pain. So, I think from here to here and your bone scan we can get that in a few days.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And as we discussed before, this is generally considered a little bit controversial. It’s not the standard therapy. So if you read a textbook about managing advanced prostate cancer it would only say that you’d give Abiraterone you’d also give an injectable suppression at the same time like Lupron. Patient: Okay. Doctor: However, as I told you before, I have used Abiraterone (Zytiga) Patient: Yes, I have also, and I think I was zero point something for over a year. Doctor: Yeah, about point one. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yes, so again, with the caveat that it would be considered unconventional therapy – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - you know given that caveat if we both acknowledge that, I would be willing to consider that for you, especially if the studies don’t show any disease or metastatic. Patient: Okay. Doctor: disease is one. And if we were both informed that this is really not the conventional therapy and yet you still want to or agree to do it. But I think as long as it’s an informed decision, I’m willing to consider that.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: -and that's when it's in the prostate. And that is when you had surgery. Okay, so the treatment here is surgery. And then we have- usually the PSA goes up and then it goes down to zero after you get your prostate taken out. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: And then it'll go back up. That is what we call biochemical recurrence. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And that's when you have a rising PSA but negative imaging. Patient: Mm. Family Member: Okay Doctor: Okay, so that means that because your prostate is out, we know that the PSA is coming from the cancer, but there's not so much of it that we can see it, so it's there somewhere we just don't know exactly where it is. That, you got radiation for back in 2007 because usually, when prostate cancer recurs, it first recurs near the prostate. Am I making sense so far? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Then if it progresses, if you do nothing, you get metastatic disease. And that's when we can see the cancer somewhere in your body either on the CAT scan or the bone scan. So that's a CT or CAT scan or the bone scan because prostate cancer goes to the bone. So when you came to me you already had surgery for localized disease, you had already had radiation, which we sometimes use for our chemical occurrence- Patient: Mm. DOC- but you still had a rising PSA and we weren't sure if you were in this biochemical recurrence bucket or in this metastatic disease bucket. Okay. So, your imaging findings, so your CAT scan here shows…so here are the, this is the summary. I’ll just write summary. We can go through this. So, what this report shows- this is a CAT scan that shows coronary artery calcification, that means there's calcium build up in your around your heart. It's not uncommon for someone your age. Small atrial hernia not important. A thyroid nodule not that important. At some point, we can do a thyroid ultrasound, but we don't need to do anything about that right this moment. So this is what- is is maybe means that it's prostate cancer a small enhancing nodule in the left prostatectomy bed, which may reflect recurrence. So when you look in the full report, what they say is that there is a it's less than once every here is 0.7 by 0.9 centimeters, so then that's like less than one centimeter. So when it's that small, it's like, really difficult. It's actually like impossible to characterize it to say like, yes, this is definitively cancer or this is not cancer. Family Member: Mhm.

Most, unless you, you are puking your guts out which is pretty rare. Most people are just, sort of, feel like that they’ve, um - “I—I- I gotta go take a nap.” Family Member: Yeah, that’s what T_ said. Doctor: So, I- I--I am just gonna go take a nap. Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: Can I just inject on the Cornell thing? Clinical trials seem to me like they are very regimen and very time consuming, and I don’t think your situation gives you that. So if you’re willing to do Germany why would you spend this time looking at Germany connection, I mean the Cornell connection, when we’re pretty sure about Germany? I just don’t want to waste your Doctor: Well, you know, if it’s the same drug, which it is, and it’s you know and- Patient: And it’s available. Doctor: You may not care that I’m saving you fifty to hundred thousand dollars but it’s those, those things. Family Member: No. But I’m just very uh the anxiety of the whole thing is, is he - Doctor: I mean the Cornell group has a lot of experience giving you know radioactive compounds, just not for this one, because they’re just starting to do it, so they’ve probably treated a thousand people, maybe they treated three or four hundred people. No wonder that matters. It’s just giving somebody radioactive stuff and making sure after that happens part of it does that big of a difference, uh? Patient: Yeah. Well if you don’t mind, checking them out. Doctor: I’ll check with them. Patient: Yeah, because- Doctor: I know the guy at Cornell really well. Doing it is just an e-mail to say, hey, here’s my patient. How long would it take to get him on the trial? What’s the deal? And um- Patient: Okay. Doctor: He says we’re, we’ve got a waiting list out six months. Then you know we’re not going that way.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Correct. So fifty percent above increase above would be fourteen points. Twenty-eight plus fourteen, that’s forty-two. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So and the PSA is measured every month. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you went on this trial – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - you have a two out of three chance of getting the stereotactic radiotherapy immediately to that lymph node. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or you can have a one out of three chance to get in the observation group first. If you go in the observation group you’re gonna get no additional therapy. You’ll be getting your PSA checked every other month.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
